messageBody:
On 6/2/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> I have been fortunate to work with very talented QA engineers who were
> absolutely brilliant at improving the tests initially supplied by the
> developers, and obviously, TDD is quite irrelevant for these QA
> departments
> since the code has already been written.


Just a slight disagreement here - I would suggest that TDD is quite relevant
if the QA department is augmenting the automated unit tests. In my
experience, it's much easier to add tests to code that has been designed for
testability. Take one developer that used TDD to deliver a project, and one
that added tests afterwards and pass the results to a talented QA engineer.
I would bet that the QA person is much more productive adding tests to the
first system.

Cheers!
Carl
